Hi Achim, 

Unfortunately I do not believe there is a lot of data regarding=
 
NEAT's performance on noisy time series.  There is reason to believe 
(ba=
sed on performance in other areas) that it may be competitive, 
but it is d=
ifficult to be certain.  It is an area for more research.

I'm not an exper=
t on GMDH either; however, it might be interesting 
to consider combining N=
EAT with GMDH.  It may be possible in 
principle to do that, for example by=
 having NEAT evolve GMDH-style 
networks, or by having NEAT evolve the topo=
logy of the network that 
GMDH then optimizes.  

Finally, there has also b=
een work with NEAT on selecting relevant 
features, called FS-NEAT (feature=
-selective NEAT):

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?whiteson:gecco05

Ultima=
tely the only way to find out how NEAT performs is to try it.  
One issue t=
hat may become important is the number of inputs you need 
to perform in th=
is domain.  If it is very large, it could be 
difficult for NEAT.  However,=
 FS-NEAT may help with that problem.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "ak=
lein07" <a.klein@...> wrote:
>
> All,
> 
> I'm a research student at Humbol=
dt University, Berlin, considering 
a 
> couple of evolutionary neural netw=
ork approaches to be used for 
> creating models of noisy time series. Conc=
erning NEAT, which seems 
> very promising to me, I do have the following q=
uestions:
> 
> How does NEAT compare (in estimating models from time series=
) to 
GMDH 
> (group method of data handling: http://www.gmdh.net) type neu=
ral 
> networks ?
> GMDH automatically selects relevant inputs, evolves the=
 topology 
> (using genetic algorithms) and estimates coefficients of 
poly=
nomial 
> transfer functions (using least squares for example). Because of =

> restricting the GA to the topology, the search space is kept 
> relative=
ly small. Like in NEAT, networks are evolved from small to 
> more complex,=
 in order find the least complex optimal solution. 
The 
> gmdh method is s=
upposed to be fast, working well on noisy, small 
> sample data, insensitiv=
e to irrelevant inputs, and creates 
explicit 
> models (algebraic equation=
s which can be analyzed).
> 
> Further questions are:
> How well does NEAT =
perform on noisy time series ? 
> 
> Does it require any enhancements to ma=
ke NEAT model (noisy) time 
> series well ?
> 
> Thank you for your help,
>=
 Achim
>
